title: Meet the women taking to the streets to protest Poland's abortion ban
description: After the draconian law was introduced last week, thousands have marched night after night. Matthew Day meets some of them

			Meet the women taking to the streets to protest Poland's abortion ban
		

			After the draconian law was introduced last week, thousands have marched night after night. Matthew Day meets some of them
		






Matthew Day



Warsaw





		2 February 2021 • 3:51pm
	






Related Topics



						Gender equality,
					



						Abortion,
					



						Poland
					









X Icon







Facebook Icon







WhatsApp Icon







Email Icon








Save







Comment speech bubble icon
























For Julia and Krystyna, both 30-something film industry professionals, there is a war to be fought in Poland, and they are on its front line. Muffled against both the freezing cold and the omnipresent danger of Covid they have taken to Warsaw’s streets to voice their fury over their now almost complete lack of abortion rights.
The two are not alone. Night after night last week cities and towns across Poland saw demonstrations large and small after a court ruling outlawing all abortion except when the pregnancy results from rape, incest or if it threatens the health or life of the mother came into force.
It has seen thousands take to the streets  - defying freezing temperatures and Covid restrictions - to protest against the curbs. Poland’s abortion laws, already some of the tightest in Europe, have become a lot tighter, and it has prompted a passionate backlash against the country’s socially conservative government that revels in its close ties to the Catholic Church.
“I believe this is something the government has planned to do for a long time and I think they finally did it as part of a war that is happening here against women and against our rights,” says Julia over a cacophony of shouted instructions from protest organisers and ominous loud-speakered warnings from the police, deployed in regimented ranks by the hundred.













				Julia and Krystyna are both 30-something professionals protesting the abortion ban in Poland
			

Credit: Matthew Day
			




“I really feel very strongly this is a war,” she continues. “I feel that nobody cares about women here. And if they really cared for babies so much they would take care of the ones who are already born with disabilities, but we can see that there was supposed to be a budget for child mental health but the ruling party was against it.
“So I don’t believe there is any support for women’s rights or children’s rights. It is the price the government pays to get the support of the Church.”
A feeling that the government is against women has been a pervasive element throughout the protests. The ruling party, Law and Justice, has long sought to portray itself as standing for traditional values. Jaroslaw Kaczynski, the party’s unmarried leader who lives alone apart from the company of his cats, has spoken about the importance of defending Poland from the apparent dangers posed by cosmopolitan cultures cultivated in the West.













				Magdelena (right) and her friend Joanna attend a protest in Warsaw
			

Credit: Matthew Day
			




“We feel ignored,” says Magdalena Blazajczyk, a sales professional, who, along with her friend Joanna, has joined a crowd of hundreds that is bringing traffic in central Warsaw to halt by occupying a roundabout. “We feel our opinion is not as important as some men who are making decisions. A lot of them don’t have kids, don’t have families but they want to decide how a woman should live.
“It is not about our country,” she adds. “We are all patriots and we love our country, but it is the people who are ruling the government that are the problem. I’m not married. I’m a single woman and that is one of the reasons I’m here because I will have a husband and have a family, and when this happens I want to feel safe in my country.”
But she, like others in the crowd, realises that for all their anger and determination to protest there is little chance of the abortion laws being liberalised under the current regime. Opposition parties have raised the prospect of tabling new abortion legislation in parliament, but for it to become law it would require support from Law and Justice MPs, something that is unlikely to happen.













				Student Aleksandra carries a sign that roughly translates as 'Never let them play you'
			

Credit: Matthew Day
			




“Sometimes I feel angry and sometimes sad, but I also feel powerless because there is nothing I can do,” explains Aleksandra, a 21-year-old geology student, who has joined the protest with three friends. “It is in the hands of the people with power. All I can do is be here and say what I want to say.”
Krystyna, the film-industry professional, strikes a similar resigned, if defiant, tone: “We will continue to protest although the current wave of protests will probably die out,” she says. “But I think the spirit is there, and hopefully we will choose a new ruling party.
“It has to end this way,” she adds. “This is something I speak about every day, it is something we speak about every day at work, we speak about it when we meet for coffee. It is the main topic right now. Until this government has gone, nothing will change.” 




The 51 per cent newsletter REFERRAL (Article)
